definition:
A *pentagon* is a 5-sided planar polygon.

Regular pentagons are of particular interest for geometers. On a regular
pentagon, the inner angles are equal to $108^\circ$. All ten diagonals
have the same length. If $s$ is the length of a side and $d$ is the
length of a diagonal, then $$\frac{d}{s}=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2};$$ that
is, the ratio between a diagonal and a side is the Golden Number.

A regular pentagon (along with its diagonals) can also be obtained as
the projection of a regular pentahedron in four dimensional space onto a
plane determined by two opposite edges. This is analogous to the way a
square with its diagonals can be obtained as the projection of a
tetrahedrononto a plane determined by two opposite edges.
